results_summary: Iron supplementation was not associated with an increased risk of P. falciparum malaria in Africa but showed a temporary increase in P. vivax risk in Asia. Iron deficiency was linked to lower malaria risk when measured with ferritin.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Africa and Asia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether daily oral vitamin B-12 supplementation during pregnancy improves maternal and infant vitamin B-12 status, alongside iron and folic acid supplementation.
results_summary: Vitamin B-12 supplementation significantly increased maternal and infant plasma vitamin B-12 concentrations and reduced markers of deficiency, though the effect on intrauterine growth retardation was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (<14 weeks of gestation) in Bangalore, India.
effective_dosage: Iron and folic acid supplements were administered throughout pregnancy (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: From <14 weeks of gestation through 6 weeks postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest evidence on how to best meet iron requirements in infants and children, focusing on safety, efficacy, and optimal strategies for preventing iron deficiency.
results_summary: Delayed cord clamping improves infant iron stores, while iron supplements before 6 months do not reduce deficiency in low-risk populations but benefit low birth weight infants. Iron supplementation reduces IDA in high-risk groups but may increase infection risk.
population_specificity: Infants, children (including low birth weight infants and school-aged children), and high-risk populations in developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of ferumoxytol-enhanced whole-body diffusion-weighted MRI as a radiation-free alternative to (18)F-FDG PET/CT for cancer staging in children and young adults.
results_summary: Ferumoxytol-enhanced whole-body diffusion-weighted MRI showed comparable sensitivity, specificity, and diagnostic accuracy to (18)F-FDG PET/CT, with no adverse events reported. The method demonstrated very good agreement with standard imaging for tumor staging (κ = 0.93).
population_specificity: Children and young adults with malignant lymphomas and sarcomas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the mechanisms of iron regulation in humans and evaluate the therapeutic applications of iron supplementation and chelation for conditions like anemia and iron overload.
results_summary: The study found that iron is essential for biological functions but toxic in excess, with systemic iron overload treatable by chelation therapy and anemia manageable via iron supplementation. Iron chelation may also have potential in treating neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, tuberculosis, and malaria, though clinical selectivity remains unestablished.
population_specificity: General human population, with specific focus on individuals with anemia, iron overload, or neurodegenerative diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional composition of horsemeat, particularly its heme iron content, and its potential health benefits compared to other meats.
results_summary: Horsemeat was found to have low fat and cholesterol levels, relatively high n-3 fatty acids, and beneficial heme iron content, suggesting potential health benefits when consumed in moderation.
population_specificity: General human consumers (no specific demographic mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence and management of anaemia and iron deficiency in newly diagnosed cancer patients in Spain, as well as the incidence of anaemia during cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that 38.6% of patients had anaemia at diagnosis, with only 32.5% receiving treatment. Among non-anaemic patients, 60.2% developed anaemia during treatment. Iron deficiency was prevalent (59%), but iron supplementation was underutilized.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed cancer patients in Spain who were treatment-naïve.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of zinc and vitamin C supplementation on hemoglobin, hematocrit levels, and immune response in patients with P. vivax malaria.
results_summary: Hemoglobin levels increased significantly in the supplementation group, while hematocrit levels increased in both groups. Immune response markers (IFN-gamma and IL-10) showed no significant changes, suggesting the hematological improvements were unrelated to immune modulation.
population_specificity: Patients with P. vivax malaria and normal baseline hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
effective_dosage: Daily zinc and vitamin C supplementation (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore alternative treatment modalities for ADHD, including iron supplementation, alongside genetic diagnosis and non-stimulant options.
results_summary: The abstract mentions iron supplementation as one of the alternative treatments considered for ADHD, but no specific results or effects of iron are detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with ADHD, including children and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal iron supplementation dose based on early pregnancy hemoglobin levels to promote maternal and infant health.
results_summary: The study is structured as a randomized clinical trial but does not yet report conclusive outcomes regarding the effectiveness of different iron doses.
population_specificity: 878 non-anemic pregnant women in early gestation and their newborns from 10 primary care centers in Catalunya, Spain.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/d, 40 mg/d, or 80 mg/d depending on hemoglobin levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intramuscular hydroxocobalamin supplementation reduces erythropoietin requirements while maintaining hemoglobin levels in hemodialysis patients with low serum B12.
results_summary: Hydroxocobalamin supplementation significantly reduced erythropoietin requirements without altering hemoglobin levels, increased serum albumin, and elevated red cell folate and serum B12 levels. Serum ferritin rose despite reduced intravenous iron usage.
population_specificity: Long-term hemodialysis patients with serum B12 < 300 pmol/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron supplementation, either oral or intravenous, with or without erythropoietin, in optimizing preoperative hemoglobin for patients with anemia.
results_summary: The study suggests that iron supplementation, particularly intravenous iron, along with erythrocyte stimulating agents (ESAs), can effectively optimize preoperative hemoglobin and red blood cell mass in anemic patients. Different formulations of intravenous iron and the indications/contraindications for ESAs are discussed.
population_specificity: Preoperative patients with anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether dietary recommendations, including the Mediterranean diet, could increase serum iron levels in depressive patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant increase in serum iron levels after six months of Mediterranean diet prescription, likely due to insufficient adherence. Iron was among the micronutrients studied, but no specific efficacy for iron supplementation was demonstrated.
population_specificity: 77 outpatients with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adherence to and effect of prenatal iron supplementation (30 mg or 60 mg with folic acid) and multiple micronutrients on under-five mortality, comparing social groups defined by maternal schooling.
results_summary: Early invitation to prenatal food supplementation combined with multiple micronutrients (including iron) reduced under-five mortality and narrowed social disparities in child survival. Women with less schooling adhered more to food supplementation, while those with more schooling adhered better to micronutrient supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in rural Matlab, Bangladesh, stratified by maternal schooling (<6 years vs. ≥6 years).
effective_dosage: 30 mg or 60 mg iron with 400 μg folic acid, or multiple micronutrients.
study_duration: From early (about 9 weeks) or usual (about 20 weeks) pregnancy until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a single high-dose vitamin A supplementation on iron status indices, anaemia, and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) among Orang Asli schoolchildren in Malaysia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in haemoglobin, serum iron, and transferrin saturation, along with a 22% reduction in IDA prevalence among children receiving vitamin A compared to placebo. Vitamin A supplementation showed a notable impact on iron status and IDA.
population_specificity: Orang Asli (aboriginal) schoolchildren in Malaysia.
effective_dosage: Single high-dose of 200,000 IU vitamin A.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron deficiency increases blood lead concentrations in infants and whether iron supplementation reduces these levels.
results_summary: Iron-deficient infants had higher blood lead concentrations than controls, which significantly decreased after iron therapy. Hemoglobin and ferritin levels also increased significantly post-treatment.
population_specificity: Infants aged 6-24 months, divided into iron-deficient (n=30) and control (n=35) groups.

study_goal: To determine whether early iron supplementation (2 mg/kg/day) at 2 weeks postnatal age improves serum ferritin levels compared to late supplementation at 6 weeks in preterm very low birth weight infants.
results_summary: Early iron supplementation significantly increased serum ferritin and hemoglobin levels at 12 weeks compared to late supplementation, with no significant differences in neonatal morbidities, anthropometric parameters, or transfusion requirements between groups.
population_specificity: Preterm very low birth weight (VLBW) infants in a tertiary care center in southern India.
study_duration: From 2 weeks to 12 weeks postnatal age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron supplementation in adults with cystic fibrosis and hypoferremic anemia would improve iron-related parameters without adversely affecting lung health or the sputum microbiome.
results_summary: Ferrous sulfate increased serum iron and transferrin saturation but did not significantly affect hemoglobin, sputum iron, pulmonary exacerbation scores, or the sputum microbiome. No untoward health effects were observed, though the study was underpowered to fully assess safety.
population_specificity: 22 adults with cystic fibrosis and hypoferremic anemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of intravenous iron in managing cancer-related anemia and iron deficiency, while also reviewing epidemiological and nonclinical data on iron's role in carcinogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that while long-term intravenous iron treatment in hemodialysis patients is not associated with increased cancer risk, epidemiological data suggest correlations between certain cancers and increased iron exposure. Nonclinical models provided limited evidence relevant to cancer patients due to high iron doses and non-clinical formulations.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with anemia and iron deficiency, as well as hemodialysis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether human milk-fed preterm infants require iron supplementation after discharge and whether iron-fortified formulae provide sufficient dietary iron until 6 months post-term.
results_summary: The study found that ferritin levels <12 μg/l were more prevalent in human milk-fed infants compared to iron-fortified formula-fed infants at 3 and 6 months post-term, suggesting that additional iron supplementation may be unnecessary for formula-fed infants.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (gestational age ~30 weeks, birth weight ~1,375-1,400 grams).
effective_dosage: Iron-fortified formulae (0.8-1.0 mg iron/100 ml); supplemented iron intake varied (2.66 mg/kg/d between term age and 3 months post-term, 1.19 mg/kg/d between 3 and 6 months post-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of oral iron supplementation versus pramipexole in treating restless legs syndrome (RLS) in patients with low-normal serum ferritin levels.
results_summary: Both oral iron and pramipexole significantly reduced RLS symptom severity after 12 weeks, with similar improvements in IRLS scores and identical response rates (46.7%). The study concluded that neither treatment was superior, suggesting potential benefits from combined therapy.
population_specificity: RLS patients with low-normal serum ferritin levels (15-50 ng/ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advances in understanding iron homeostasis in chronic kidney disease (CKD) and explore potential improvements in anemia management for CKD patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights dysregulated iron homeostasis in CKD and its role in anemia, noting that iron supplementation is a key treatment but lacks rigorous large-scale trials. Genetic and animal model studies provide insights into iron regulation and potential therapeutic advances.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: To determine whether iron treatment effectively treats anaemia after nonvariceal acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding and compare the efficacy of a 3-month oral iron regimen versus a single intravenous iron dose.
results_summary: Iron treatment significantly increased haemoglobin levels from week 4 onwards compared to placebo, with intravenous iron being more effective than oral iron in replenishing iron stores. The proportion of patients with anaemia was significantly higher in the placebo group than in the treatment groups.
population_specificity: Patients with nonvariceal acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding and anaemia (n=97).
effective_dosage: Single intravenous administration of 1000 mg iron or oral iron treatment (200 mg daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the value of supplemental nutrients, including iron, for at-risk populations based on evidence from multivitamin/mineral studies.
results_summary: The committee noted the value of iron supplementation for at-risk populations, though evidence for the general healthy population was insufficient. Recent studies suggest potential benefits, but some reports still find no benefit from multivitamin/mineral supplements.
population_specificity: At-risk populations (e.g., those with deficiencies or chronic diseases) and the general healthy population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability, toxicity, and stability of the iron sucrose originator Venofer® and the generic iron sucrose AZAD (ISA) in human THP-1 and HepG2 cells.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between Venofer® and ISA in bioavailability, toxicity, and stability in vitro, indicating identical physico-chemical features and bioavailability for the generic iron sucrose.
population_specificity: Human THP-1 and HepG2 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare oxidative stress in first-trimester pregnancies with and without iron supplementation.
results_summary: Iron supplementation was associated with significantly higher oxidative stress (measured by serum γ-glutamyl transferase levels) and increased cases of oligohydramnios compared to placebo and folate groups. Maternal weight gain was also lower in the iron-supplemented group.
population_specificity: 108 women in the first trimester of normal pregnancies.
study_duration: Until delivery (follow-up at 14th week of gestation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of iron supplementation on iron status and physical performance in nonanemic female rowers during endurance training.
results_summary: Iron supplementation improved iron stores (serum ferritin) and energetic efficiency during endurance exercise, with slower lactate response and greater improvements in energy expenditure compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Nonanemic female rowers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-dose tocotrienol supplementation on the expression of frataxin isoforms (FXN-1, FXN-2, FXN-3) in Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA) patients and healthy subjects, and to assess potential functional roles of these isoforms.
results_summary: Tocotrienol significantly increased FXN-3 expression in FRDA patients without affecting FXN-1 or FXN-2. Computational modeling suggested FXN-2 and FXN-3 may have functional roles similar to FXN-1, and the FXN-3 increase appeared independent of PPARG expression.
population_specificity: Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA) patients and healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the necessity and challenges of iron supplementation in post-RYGB patients to prevent iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency anemia occurs in 6%-50% of post-RYGB patients, necessitating lifelong iron supplementation. Ferrous sulfate, while effective, causes constipation, potentially reducing patient adherence.
population_specificity: Post-Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) patients.
study_duration: Lifelong supplementation implied, but exact study duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review issues related to iron toxicity and assess the safety and efficacy of intravenous iron in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous iron effectively raises hemoglobin levels and reduces erythropoiesis-stimulating agent dose requirements, but its safety regarding patient-centered outcomes remains inadequately studied. Potential safety concerns were noted, but most studies had small sample sizes and unclear clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with advanced kidney disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and impact of routine oral iron supplementation in malaria-endemic regions, particularly its adverse effects on iron-sufficient individuals.
results_summary: The study found that routine oral iron supplementation had adverse effects in iron-sufficient subjects, leading to a moratorium on such programs in malaria-endemic areas. It highlights unresolved dilemmas and suggests tailored approaches like targeted supplementation and antimalarial prophylaxis.
population_specificity: Young children in malaria-endemic regions (specifically Pemba Island, Tanzania).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and management of anemia and iron deficiency in non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (ND-CKD) patients under nephrology care.
results_summary: The study found high and persistent prevalence of anemia and iron deficiency in ND-CKD patients, with significant clinical inertia in iron supplementation despite identified deficiencies.
population_specificity: 755 prevalent ND-CKD stage 3b-5 patients followed in 19 nephrology clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between iron availability, human growth, obesity, and obesity-related diseases, proposing that modern iron abundance may contribute to these conditions.
results_summary: The study suggests that increased iron availability promotes growth and may correlate with obesity, proposing that obesity-related diseases reflect iron overabundance. However, testing these associations is challenging due to widespread iron fortification and supplementation.
population_specificity: General human populations, particularly those in societies with extensive iron fortification and supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a dietary supplement containing vitamin K2 and vitamin D on bone mineral density in children with thalassemia major suffering from thalassemic osteopathy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in bone mineral density and Z-score at the lumbar spine area, particularly in prepubertal children, over a 12-month period. There was also a non-significant decrease in the ratio of undercarboxylated to carboxylated osteocalcin.
population_specificity: Twenty children (12 girls, 8 boys; aged 3-18 years) with β-thalassemia major undergoing regular blood transfusion and iron chelation therapy.
effective_dosage: 50 mcg menaquinone-7 (vitamin K2) and 5 mcg calcitriol (vitamin D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intravenous (IV) iron and erythropoietin (EPO) in reducing perioperative red cell transfusions.
results_summary: Preoperative IV iron therapy showed earlier and more robust hemoglobin recovery in iron-deficient patients compared to oral iron. A short preoperative regimen of EPO or a single dose of EPO plus IV iron significantly reduced transfusion rates, though IV iron may rarely cause severe anaphylactic reactions, and EPO may increase thromboembolism risk in spinal surgery patients.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing perioperative care, particularly those with preoperative iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and safety of daily iron supplementation in primary-school-aged children, focusing on cognitive and hematologic outcomes.
results_summary: Iron supplementation improved global cognitive scores, IQ in anemic children, attention, concentration, and growth metrics while reducing anemia risk by 50% and iron deficiency by 79%. Safety data were limited but suggested good tolerability.
population_specificity: Primary-school-aged children (5-12 years), predominantly in low- or middle-income settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence of micronutrient deficiencies, including iron, in PKU patients and discuss their clinical implications.
results_summary: The study found that iron is among the micronutrients with reported inadequacies in PKU patients, but the relationship between dietary intake and nutritional status is complex and influenced by multiple factors.
population_specificity: Patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) following dietary treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of hepcidin in iron homeostasis and the challenges of iron absorption and supplementation in obese patients, particularly after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that elevated hepcidin in obese patients leads to functional iron deficiency, and iron malabsorption post-bariatric surgery exacerbates this, often causing anemia and fatigue. Intravenous iron supplements were shown to rapidly restore iron status and alleviate symptoms more effectively than oral supplements.
population_specificity: Obese patients, particularly those who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and optimal administration methods of iron supplementation for treating anemia and iron deficiency in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous iron (particularly ferric carboxymaltose) is more effective and convenient than oral iron or iron sucrose for moderate to severe anemia in IBD, while oral iron may suffice for mild cases. Iron sucrose is safe and effective but less convenient, and blood transfusions should be reserved for acute, life-threatening situations.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) experiencing anemia or iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation of international guidelines for managing iron deficiency and anemia in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients, focusing on the preferred route of iron supplementation.
results_summary: The study found significant variation in diagnostic tests and treatment approaches for IBD-associated anemia across Europe, with most patients receiving oral iron despite guidelines recommending intravenous iron. Iron deficiency was detected in 76% of patients, and nearly all (92%) received iron supplementation, but only 28% received intravenous iron.
population_specificity: IBD patients with anemia or iron deficiency from nine European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine sex- and menopause-specific associations between iron status (ferritin and hemoglobin levels) and subsequent cognitive performance in adults.
results_summary: The study found an inverse association between ferritin levels and cognitive performance in postmenopausal women (phonemic fluency) and premenopausal women aged ≥46 (composite cognitive measure and forward digit span). No significant associations were observed in men or with hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: 1539 men, 1431 pre-/perimenopausal women, and 962 postmenopausal women from the French Supplémentation en Vitamines et Minéraux Antioxydants Study cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of once-weekly and twice-weekly iron supplements in improving haemoglobin concentration and reducing anaemia prevalence in school children.
results_summary: The study found no significant increase in haemoglobin concentration or reduction in anaemia prevalence in children receiving iron supplements compared to the unsupplemented group. Anaemia prevalence increased in all groups during follow-up, suggesting limited efficacy of the intervention.
population_specificity: School children and adolescents aged 5-17 years in north-west Pakistan.
effective_dosage: 200 mg ferrous sulphate (63 mg elemental iron) once-weekly for 24 weeks or twice-weekly for 12 weeks.
study_duration: 12 or 24 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether routine supplementation of iron is necessary for term infants, given the adequacy of standard nutritional options like human milk or infant formulas.
results_summary: The study found that recommended dietary allowances (RDAs) for iron are not adequately met by human milk or standard formulas, suggesting that iron supplements are needed for term infants. It also indicated that RDAs may be overestimated for most vitamins and minerals.
population_specificity: Term infants during the first year of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether providing a micronutrient powder (MNP) with or without iron affected the incidence of malaria in children living in a high malaria-burden area.
results_summary: The study found that daily use of an MNP with iron did not increase malaria incidence and was associated with a lower malaria risk compared to the no-iron group, though the difference lost statistical significance after adjusting for baseline iron deficiency and anemia status.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 35 months in rural Ghana, a high malaria-burden area.
effective_dosage: 12.5 mg/d of iron in the MNP.
study_duration: 5 months of intervention followed by 1 month of monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish gestational age-specific cord blood reference ranges for iron status parameters in preterm infants to assess iron nutrition status.
results_summary: The study found that cord blood concentration ranges for iron status parameters in preterm infants differ significantly from adult reference ranges, suggesting adult ranges may not be suitable for defining iron status in preterm infants.
population_specificity: Preterm infants until term-equivalent age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron supplementation is safe and beneficial for HIV-infected children with moderate anemia in malaria-endemic regions, focusing on hemoglobin levels, HIV progression, and morbidity.
results_summary: Iron supplementation improved hemoglobin levels, reduced persistent anemia, and enhanced CD4 percentage response but increased malaria incidence, particularly in the first 3 months.
population_specificity: HIV-infected Malawian children aged 6-59 months with moderate anemia (hemoglobin 7.0-9.9 g/dL).
effective_dosage: 3 mg/kg/day of elemental iron with multivitamins (vitamins A, C, and D).
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, 6 months of follow-up.

study_goal: To compare the effects of three oral iron compounds (ferrous sulfate, NaFeEDTA, and IPM) on circulating non-transferrin-bound iron (NTBI) and plasma iron levels in women with marginal iron stores.
results_summary: Ferrous sulfate produced significantly higher serum iron and NTBI responses compared to water and the other two iron compounds. NaFeEDTA and IPM suppressed NTBI appearance, suggesting safer profiles for iron supplementation in malarial areas.
population_specificity: 10 Guatemalan women with marginal iron stores.
effective_dosage: 100 mg of iron from each compound, administered once.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intravenous iron therapy, focusing on its effects on hemoglobin levels, transfusion requirements, and infection risk.
results_summary: Intravenous iron increased hemoglobin concentration and reduced transfusion risk but was associated with a higher infection risk compared to oral or no iron supplementation. The benefits were more pronounced when used with erythroid stimulating agents (ESAs) or in patients with lower baseline ferritin levels.
population_specificity: 10,605 patients from randomized controlled trials (no specific demographic details provided).
interactions: Enhanced efficacy when used with ESAs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiology, diagnostic criteria, and therapeutic recommendations for iron supplementation in heart failure patients with anemia.
results_summary: The study highlights the diagnostic criteria for iron deficiency in heart failure patients and discusses the benefits of iron supplementation, though specific efficacy data are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and anemia, including those with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ferrous fumarate alone versus combined with ascorbic acid on hemoglobin levels and red blood cell indices in female regular blood donors.
results_summary: The combination of ferrous fumarate 200 mg/day with ascorbic acid 500 mg/day significantly accelerated recovery of hemoglobin and red blood cell indices compared to ferrous fumarate alone. All regimens were well-tolerated with no reported side effects or withdrawals.
population_specificity: Female regular blood donors
effective_dosage: Ferrous fumarate 200 mg/day; combinations with ascorbic acid 100 mg/day or 500 mg/day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand iron metabolism and utilization in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA), including the impact of infection, inflammation, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that while iron supplementation is necessary for CKD patients with IDA, iron metabolism can be disrupted by factors like infection or inflammation. Alternative tests for IDA may be more accurate as they are less affected by external factors.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of nutrient supplementation, including iron, on neurodevelopment in low birthweight infants.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that few trials support the hypothesis that nutritional supplementation, including iron, improves neurodevelopment in low birthweight infants, with many studies limited by small sample sizes and methodological shortcomings.
population_specificity: Low birthweight infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between gestational nutrition, including iron, and brain development in children.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that iron is one of the micronutrients with credible evidence linking it to brain development in healthy children, though single-nutrient supplementation is less adequate than complex formulae. Long-term impacts on neurodevelopment require further investigation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal multiple micronutrient (MM) supplementation, including iron, improves intrauterine growth compared to iron-folate supplementation.
results_summary: Prenatal MM supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of low birthweight (LBW) and small for gestational age (SGA) and increased mean birthweight by 55 g compared to iron-folate supplementation. Greater reductions in LBW and SGA were observed with supplements containing 60 mg of iron, though differences from 30 mg iron were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in settings where micronutrient deficiencies are common.
effective_dosage: 30 mg and 60 mg of iron (as part of MM supplementation).
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron supplementation in preventing iron deficiency and its associated cognitive and behavioral problems in low birthweight infants.
results_summary: The study found that 2 mg/kg daily of dietary iron prevents iron deficiency anemia in LBW infants without adverse effects and reduces behavioral problems at 3 years in infants with birthweights 2,000-2,500 g. VLBW infants require 2-3 mg/kg per day.
population_specificity: Low birthweight (1,500-2,500 g) and very low birthweight (<1,500 g) infants.
effective_dosage: 2 mg/kg daily for LBW infants; 2-3 mg/kg daily for VLBW infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate iron levels in diabetes and hypertension patients with/without hemodialysis and assess the effects of erythropoietin, iron treatment, and vitamin supplementation.
results_summary: Serum iron levels in hemodialysis patients were similar to healthy controls, except for a significant difference between diabetic controls and diabetic nephropathy patients. Iron treatment did not affect erythrocyte folate levels.
population_specificity: Diabetes and hypertension patients with/without hemodialysis, including healthy, hypertensive, and diabetic controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent versus daily antenatal iron supplementation on maternal and infant outcomes, particularly birth weight and cognitive development.
results_summary: The study found no clinically significant difference in birth weight between intermittent and daily iron supplementation. However, infants of mothers receiving twice-weekly iron-folic acid (IFA) showed higher cognitive scores at 6 months compared to daily IFA, suggesting potential benefits of intermittent dosing.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (<16 weeks gestation) in rural Viet Nam.
effective_dosage: Daily IFA, twice-weekly IFA, or twice-weekly multiple micronutrient (MMN) supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron-rich snacks cooked in iron pots could increase iron content and improve hemoglobin status in preschool children.
results_summary: Cooking in iron pots increased iron content in snacks by 16.2%. After 4 months of supplementation, children showed a significant 7.9% increase in hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: 27 preschool children (mean age 2.9 ± 0.9 years, 12 boys).
effective_dosage: Mean iron content of 2.1mg per serving (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of oral iron supplementation on iron status and physical performance in iron-depleted female athletes.
results_summary: The study found that oral iron supplementation (100-mg FeSO4·d) improved iron status and may enhance physical performance in iron-depleted female athletes. Screening using hemoglobin and serum ferritin was recommended for at-risk female athletes.
population_specificity: Iron-depleted female athletes.

study_goal: To assess the impact of iron supplementation, combined with deworming, on cognitive abilities and educational achievement in school-age children.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact on hemoglobin levels, concentration levels, or educational test scores despite a reduction in soil-transmitted helminth infections.
population_specificity: School-age children in Sri Lanka
effective_dosage: Weekly iron supplementation (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of iron in two nutritional supplement formulations (A and B) using in vitro and in vivo methods.
results_summary: In vitro results showed 0.70% and 0.80% iron availability for formulations A and B, respectively. In vivo studies indicated low iron absorption, with a coefficient of variation Δ < 0.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine iron status, incidence of iron deficiency/overload, and related biomarkers in neonates with alloimmune HDFN up to 3 months of age, comparing those treated with and without intrauterine transfusion (IUT).
results_summary: Iron overload was common at birth (70%) but decreased over time (50% at 1 month, 18% at 3 months), with only one case of iron deficiency at 3 months. IUT recipients had higher ferritin and lower hemoglobin at birth.
population_specificity: Neonates with alloimmune hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the completeness of reporting for trial setting and health worker cadre in iron and folic acid supplementation trials for pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that while most trials reported facility type and location (96%), details like facility descriptors (26%) and population descriptors (54%) were less common. Only 34% of trials described the health workers delivering the intervention, and just 4% reported training procedures.
population_specificity: Pregnant women receiving iron and folic acid supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cobalamin supplementation affects hematological parameters in infants with biochemical signs of impaired cobalamin function and to assess the association between iron status and erythrocyte parameters.
results_summary: Cobalamin supplementation improved markers of impaired cobalamin function but had no effect on hematological cell counts. Iron-restricted erythropoiesis was observed, with male gender and high weight gain from birth being the strongest predictors of low iron status.
population_specificity: 4-month-old infants with biochemical signs of impaired cobalamin function.
effective_dosage: 400 μg cobalamin (single intramuscular injection at 6 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of iron in treating anemia during pregnancy, including its efficacy and alternative treatments for severe cases.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency anemia accounts for 75% of anemias in pregnancy, with oral iron supplementation being the recommended treatment. Parenteral iron and erythropoietin are alternatives for severe or refractory cases.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with anemia, particularly iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of daily iron supplementation (with or without zinc) on child development, including motor and language development, in relation to health factors like malaria and hemoglobin levels.
results_summary: Iron supplementation (with folic acid) had positive effects on motor development but negative effects on language development in both age groups. Zinc alone negatively affected language development in older children (10-14 months). Malaria incidence negatively impacted health and development outcomes.
population_specificity: Zanzibari children aged 5-9 months (n = 106) and 10-14 months (n = 141).
effective_dosage: 12.5 mg iron + 50 μg folic acid (FeFA), with or without 10 mg zinc (Zn), daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) metabolites and hematopoietic adverse effects, including iron-related outcomes, in renal transplant recipients.
results_summary: The study found that anemia was more frequent in MMF-treated patients, with higher plasma iron concentrations observed, but iron supplementation was ineffective in patients with declined renal function. MPAG pharmacokinetic parameters negatively correlated with hemoglobin and hematocrit, suggesting MPAG may predict MMF-induced anemia.
population_specificity: Renal transplant recipients in the late post-transplant period (n = 61 MMF-treated patients out of 106 total participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-supplementation of iron and vitamin C improves biomarkers of oxidative stress more effectively than iron alone in non-anemic iron-deficient females.
results_summary: Both iron and iron + vitamin C supplementation significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA) and increased antioxidant capacity (TAC) and vitamin C levels, but co-supplementation did not provide additional benefits over iron alone for oxidative stress. Iron + vitamin C significantly increased serum vitamin C levels more than iron alone.
population_specificity: 60 non-anemic iron-deficient girls
effective_dosage: 50 mg/day elemental iron or 50 mg/day elemental iron + 500 mg/day ascorbic acid

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of trivalent iron (FeIII) in promoting chronic inflammation through the formation of proteolysis-resistant fibrin clots and explore potential interventions like iron chelators and free radical scavengers.
results_summary: The study found that trivalent iron (FeIII) catalyzes the conversion of fibrinogen into parafibrin, a fibrin-like polymer resistant to degradation, contributing to chronic inflammation and cardiovascular disease. Amphiphilic substances were studied for their effects on iron- and thrombin-induced fibrinogen polymerization, suggesting iron chelation and free radical scavengers as potential preventive measures.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal model implied, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence and consequences of iron deficiencies in obese patients before and after bariatric surgery and provide recommendations for screening and supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiencies and anemia are prevalent in obese patients scheduled for bariatric surgery and may worsen postoperatively, impacting morbidity, mortality, and quality of life. Treatment of these deficiencies improves patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese patients scheduled for or undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: To compare the effects of intravenous (i.v.) iron versus oral (p.o.) iron on functional capacity and anemia correction in heart failure patients with anemia.
results_summary: I.v. iron improved peak oxygen consumption (peak VO2) by 3.5 ml/kg/min, while p.o. iron showed no improvement. Both i.v. and p.o. iron increased ferritin and transferrin saturation (TSat) levels, with similar hemoglobin increases across all groups.
population_specificity: Anemic heart failure patients with preserved renal function, low transferrin saturation, and low-to-moderately elevated ferritin levels.
effective_dosage: Iron Sucrose i.v. 200 mg once a week for 5 weeks; ferrous sulfate 200 mg p.o. three times daily for 8 weeks.
study_duration: 5 weeks for i.v. iron, 8 weeks for p.o. iron.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of directly observed home-based daily iron therapy (DOHBIT) versus unsupervised self-treatment in reducing anemia among rural women and adolescent girls.
results_summary: DOHBIT significantly reduced anemia prevalence (16.8% vs. 35.3%), increased hemoglobin levels (70.2% vs. 42.2% achieved ≥2 g/dL rise), and showed higher adherence (93% vs. 60%) compared to unsupervised treatment, with a nonsignificant trend toward fewer side effects (3.5% vs. 6.7%).
population_specificity: Rural women and adolescent girls with anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of zinc deficiency on iron status indicators in pregnant women and compare the efficacy of combined iron-zinc supplementation versus iron-only supplementation.
results_summary: Iron-zinc supplementation was more effective in raising Hb and serum ferritin levels among iron-deficient pregnant women compared to iron-only supplementation. Women with low plasma zinc levels had a higher likelihood of iron deficiency at recruitment.
population_specificity: Pregnant women attending antenatal care in the Upper West Region of Ghana.
effective_dosage: 40 mg elemental iron as ferrous sulphate (control group); 40 mg zinc as zinc gluconate + 40 mg iron as ferrous sulphate (intervention group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of iron supplementation on fatty acid desaturase activity in young women.
results_summary: Iron supplementation improved iron status but had no significant effect on desaturase activity. A decrease in plasma zinc concentrations was observed in the supplemented group, suggesting an antagonistic interaction between iron and zinc.
population_specificity: Young women (mean age ~25 years, BMI ~21.5 kg/m²)
interactions: Antagonism between iron and zinc noted (decreased plasma zinc concentrations in supplemented group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact, adverse drug reactions, and compliance of weekly versus daily iron-folic acid supplementation in adolescent girls with iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: Weekly iron-folic acid supplementation showed similar hemoglobin improvement as daily supplementation but with fewer adverse reactions (8.3% vs. 13.35%) and better compliance (1.3±3.15 vs. 6.1±10.98 unconsumed tablets).
population_specificity: Adolescent girls (10-19 years) with iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin <12 gm%) from an urban slum area in India.
effective_dosage: Not specified (weekly vs. daily iron-folic acid supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of two micronutrient powder formulations (with or without zinc) on iron-deficiency anemia, growth, and morbidity in young children.
results_summary: Micronutrient powders reduced iron-deficiency anemia significantly but were associated with increased diarrheal episodes and respiratory morbidities, with only a small positive effect on growth.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 2 years in urban and rural Sindh, Pakistan.
effective_dosage: Daily micronutrient powder (with or without 10 mg zinc) from 6 to 18 months of age.
